Article Title: Bhavish Aggarwal’s Ola Electric receives another notice from CCPA; gets 15 days deadline to…
Article Text:
Here’s what Ola Electric said in its exchange filing



Ola Electric faces investigation

Bhavish Aggarwal-led Ola Electric has received yet another show-cause notice from the Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA). In a December 5, 2024, exchange filing, the company disclosed that the CCPA has requested additional documents and information following its earlier response to the authority. Ola Electric said that it has received an email dated December 4, 2024 from the CCPA.The company received a show cause notice from CCPA on October 7, 2024 for “alleged violation of consumer rights, misleading advertisement and unfair trade practices”. The company then said that it has resolved 99.1 per cent of the complaints out of 10,644 complaints received from CCPA.The company said: “With reference to our previous intimation to the exchange dated October 07, 2024 and October 21, 2024, regarding the intimation of Show Cause Notice received by Ola Electric Mobility Limited (“the Company”) from the Central Consumer Protection Authority (“CCPA”), we would like to inform you that the Company has received further communication from the CCPA via email dated December 04, 2024, seeking additional documents and information in relation to the previous response submitted by the Company.”It further stated that “The CCPA has provided a timeline of 15 days from the date of email communication for the Company to submit the response in respect of seeking additional documents and information. The Company will ensure a timely response within the specified timeframe.”In November this year, the regulatory authority asked the Bureau of Indian Standards to conduct a detailed investigation over its consumer complaint redressal practices. In an earnings call last month, CEO Bhavish Aggarwal said that the complaints were mostly for "minor" issues. He said “Two-thirds of it actually are just minor issues like loose parts or customers unfamiliar with the software used”.

The company is reportedly developing a multimodal AI model capable of processing images, video, and text.While Bezos stepped down as CEO in 2021 to concentrate on Blue Origin, his rocket company, he remains Amazon's executive chairman. He continues to support current CEO Andy Jassy and the leadership team, mirroring a trend seen with other tech founders like Google's Larry Page and Sergey Brin, who returned to assist with AI initiatives.Bezos is optimistic about the company's future, drawing parallels to other tech leaders reinvesting in their original companies during the AI revolution. His deep engagement suggests Amazon is positioning itself as a serious contender in the rapidly expanding artificial intelligence market."I'll always be there to help, and right now, I'm putting a lot of time into it," Bezos said. Article Title: Zerodha CEO answers biggest insurance question: Why claims are rejected and what to and not to do
Article Text:
Kamath highlights why claims are rejected

Waiting period denial: Insurers often set waiting periods for specific illness and PEDs. Review these with your advisor when buying a policy

Non-coverage: Some treatments are permanently excluded from coverage (eg. drug abuse, etc) Review the policy/consult your advisor to understand these limitations fully.

Fraudulent claims: Claims may be rejected for non-disclosure of critical medical information. As a rule of thumb, always disclose your PEDs during your application.

Blacklisted hospitals: Insurers may deny claims if treatment is received at hospitals excluded from their coverage. Check your insurer’s list of excluded hospitals before admission.

Unnecessary hospitalisation: Claims may be denied if hospitalisation is deemed unnecessary (eg. fever).

Insurer Delays: The insurer may delay cashless approval for further investigation.

Possible PED: Claims may be questioned if a PED is suspected.

Navigating the complexities of insurance can be daunting, especially when faced with a claim rejection. Nithin Kamath , CEO of Zerodha, an online brokerage firm, recently addressed a common concern: why insurance claims get denied. Kamath highlighted a crucial point: many people lack comprehensive understanding of their insurance policies' coverage and exclusions. This often leads to confusion and disappointment when claims are rejected.In a post on X (formerly known as Twitter) Kamath emphasized the importance of thoroughly reading and understanding your insurance policy . This includes identifying exclusions and pre-existing conditions that might limit coverage. “Having insurance alone isn't enough. Just because you have insurance doesn't mean all your claims will be processed. Insurance companies often don't pay claims in full or flat-out reject the claims. It's important to know the common reasons why claims get rejected and what you can do about it,” Kamath said in a post.Kamath also acknowledged that facing claim rejection can be stressful. He encouraged individuals to seek guidance from insurance advisors or legal professionals if needed throughout the process.
Article Summary: Nithin Kamath, CEO of Zerodha, recently addressed a common concern: why insurance claims get denied. Kamath highlighted a crucial point: many people lack comprehensive understanding of their insurance policies' coverage and exclusions. This often leads to confusion and disappointment when claims are rejected.

Article Title: Nvidia may be ready to take on Intel in one of its biggest ‘fortresses’
Article Text:
How this chip plant may not completely cut Nvidia’s Taiwan ‘ties’

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is reportedly talking with Nvidia about manufacturing its Blackwell artificial intelligence (AI) chips at its new Arizona plant. If these rumoured talks go through, TSMC may potentially secure another major customer for the facility. Last month, Intel was awarded nearly $8 billion in funding from the US Department of Commerce to boost its semiconductor manufacturing and packaging capabilities in multiple sites including Arizona. This funding, which was provided through the CHIPS and Science Act aims to strengthen domestic chip production and reduce reliance on foreign manufacturers. With TSMC reportedly in talks with Nvidia to produce its AI chips at this plant, it can affect Intel’s AI chip goals. When made in the US, Nvidia may offer its AI chips to its customers at a more competitive price.As per the latest annual tally by the Arizona Republic confirmed that Intel is one of largest non-governmental employers in this US state. With nearly 12,000 employees in Chandler, this makes the chipmaker a significant contributor to the state's economy and workforce.A report by the news agency Reuters cited three sources familiar with the matter (who remained anonymous) to claim the Nvidia-TSMC Arizona plant is scheduled to begin volume production next year and is already preparing to manufacture the chips early next year. Nvidia's Blackwell AI chips, unveiled in March this year, have been in high demand for generative AI and accelerated computing tasks. These chips are said to be 30 times faster at tasks like serving up answers from chatbots. Currently manufactured in Taiwan, producing them in Arizona would also align with US efforts to boost domestic chip production.Two sources also reportedly claimed that Apple and Advanced Micro Devices are a part of Nvidia’s list of customers that will be supplied from the Arizona plant.While TSMC may have plans to manufacture the front-end process of Nvidia's Blackwell chips in Arizona, the chips will still need to be sent back to Taiwan for packaging. The Arizona facility reportedly lacks the necessary **chip on wafer on substrate** (CoWoS) capacity required for the Blackwell chips, two sources added. Currently, all of TSMC's CoWoS capacity is based in Taiwan.TSMC, the world’s largest contract chipmaker based in Taiwan, is also investing tens of billions of dollars into the construction of three facilities in Phoenix. The project has received substantial subsidies from the US government, which aims to boost semiconductor manufacturing within the country.
Article Summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is reportedly talking with Nvidia about manufacturing its Blackwell artificial intelligence (AI) chips at its new Arizona plant. Last month, Intel was awarded nearly $8 billion in funding from the US Department of Commerce to boost its semiconductor manufacturing and packaging capabilities.

Article Title: Government sends notice to WhatsApp after 'scam alarm' from telecom regulator TRAI
Article Text:
The big jurisdiction problem with WhatsApp, Signal and Telegram

The 'big OTT scam problem' Airtel, Reliance Jio and Vodafone-Idea face

How fraudsters scam users on OTT apps

The Ministry of Electronics and IT (MeitY) has reportedly urged Meta Platforms, the parent company of WhatsApp, to address scams originating on the messaging platform. This follows a request from India’s telecom regulator for intervention. According to an Economic Times report quoting MeitY secretary S. Krishnan, the ministry is actively addressing the issue with Meta. “This is an ongoing process. Scammers will always find new ways, which is a cause for concern,” Krishnan told ET.Krishnan further said that the government is in a regular dialogue with stakeholders particularly WhatsApp and added that users need to be cautious and raise complaints even in the case of WhatsApp. “If there is some wrong content, there is a process. The IT rules require these companies to have a grievance officer with whom users can raise issues. They can raise it either within the app or outside. In case, the issue is not dealt with, there is also a grievance appellate committee.”Recently, the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (Trai) asked MeitY to probe and prevent calls and messages sent out by scamsters using WhatsApp. “WhatsApp calls at present, are being looked at by MeitY, so on that we have already written to the ministry saying that Trai is already working in respect to voice calls and SMS, and requested them to take appropriate action,” Trai chairman Anil Kumar Lahoti told ET in a recent interaction.The OTT apps like WhatsApp, Signal and Telegram currently fall under MeitY’s mandate in terms of regulatory compliance- not under The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (Trai) and the telecom department. The telecom regulator is pushing the Ministry of Electronics and IT (Meity) to take strong steps to check rampant instances of spam and phishing communications that are rapidly shifting to over-the-top (OTT) apps, such as WhatsApp and Telegram.An official said while WhatsApp is cooperating with the DoT to some extent and has blocked numbers as requested by the government, there is no visible control yet over Telegram and Signal-platforms that need to take concrete steps to curb scams. However, what makes WhatsApp's case is its huge user base in India.The telecom operators -- Airtel, Reliance Jio and Vodafone-Idea -- have been highlighting the issue of rising instances of spam on OTT platforms and all the measures to control the menace do not work on OTTs as they are not regulated, either by DoT or Trai.Every time the regulator asks the telcos to block numbers for spam, their corresponding OTT numbers too have to be blocked. But since telcos can't do it, the numbers are provided to platforms like WhatsApp, Telegram by the DoT for blocking, who have to do that at their end. But unlike telcos, the OTT platforms are not bound by any licence to block the numbers. Further, there are international numbers, from which spam continues to come and telcos have no control over it.The fraudsters have been abusing WhatsApp to commit financial frauds. Modus operandi includes asking for screen share and taking remote access of a smartphone to steal personal data, and in other cases asking for a one-time password (OTP) to swindle money from a bank account.
Article Summary: The Ministry of Electronics and IT (MeitY) has reportedly urged Meta Platforms, the parent company of WhatsApp, to address scams originating on the messaging platform. This follows a request from India’s telecom regulator for intervention. Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (Trai) asked MeitY to probe and prevent calls and messages sent out by scamsters using WhatsApp.

Developer Brent Franson says that the AI was trained on a dataset of more than 1,200 life expectancy studies with some 53 million participants. The results, he says, are a ‘pretty significant’ improvement on the standard life-table expectations.Despite its somewhat morbid concept—a "fond farewell" death-day card featuring the Grim Reaper—the app has gained traction in the Health and Fitness category. It is free to use, while you will need a subscription to show a clock counting down to my estimated death. According to market intelligence firm Sensor Tower, the app has around 1,25,000 downloads till date.“Have you ever asked yourself 'when will I die?', our advanced life expectancy calculator will accurately* predict your death date for you depending on where you live, how much you smoke and your lifestyle to show your own death clock countdown. To predict your death date, simply input your date of birth, sex, smoking habits, your BMI and the country you live in. If you don't know your BMI simply use the BMI calculator form,” the app reads.Death Clock predictions are based on extensive medical studies and health data, with AI providing personalized suggestions for a healthier lifestyle. The idea is to encourage individuals to take better care of their health, using the predictions as a framework for decision-making.As mentioned, the app offers personalised suggestions to users. Avoid consuming too much processed foods, refined sugars, and unhealthy fats.Limit alcohol intake. While occasional social drinking is usually okay, heavy or prolonged drinking can lead to a number of health issues including liver disease, cardiovascular problems, and cancer.Try to get a good night's sleep. Quality sleep is important for overall health and well-being. It affects mood, memory, and healing processes.Regular screenings and medical check-ups can help detect problems early. This is especially important for conditions that don't always show noticeable symptoms, like high blood pressure or high cholesterol.Long-term stress can lead to a number of health issues. Practice stress management techniques like mindfulness, meditation, yoga, or other relaxation exercises.Relationships and social interactions are vital for mental health. Loneliness and social isolation can lead to depression and cognitive decline.Keep your mind active. Lifelong learning, reading, solving puzzles, or other brain-engaging activities can help to keep your mind sharp and potentially delay the onset of cognitive decline.While it’s important to note that these AI-driven tools aren’t guaranteed to provide exact dates, there are concerns about privacy and data security, as users must input sensitive information, which could be exploited by companies or malicious actors.

Article Title: Naukri.com parent Info Edge files fraud complaint against Rahul Yadav, founder of its portfolio company
Article Text:
Rahul Yadav, founder, 4B Networks

Strained relationship

Info Edge , the parent company of the jobs listing portal Naukri, has filed a first information report (FIR) against Rahul Yadav, the founder of its portfolio company 4B Networks, and others, alleging fraudulent misuse of funds.“An FIR has been registered by the Bandra Police Station (Mumbai Police) on November 29, 2024 against Rahul Yadav, Devesh Singh, Pratik Choudhary, Sanjay Saini (and unnamed others) in connection with 4B Networks, alleging inter alia commitment of certain fraudulent acts involving 4B Networks’ funds,” Info Edge said in a stock exchange filing on Saturday.Rahul Yadav is also the cofounder of Housing.com.In July last year, Info Edge initiated arbitration proceedings against 4B Networks after the startup failed to provide crucial information regarding its operations and management for a forensic audit. Deloitte was appointed to conduct the audit after 4B Networks did not disclose details of financial transactions and related-party activities requested by the investor.Info Edge stated that the FIR would have no material financial impact on its business operations. The consumer internet group had previously written off its equity investment of Rs 276 crore in 4B Networks during the December 2022 quarter, citing excessive cash burn, liquidity issues, and uncertainty regarding funding options. At that time, Info Edge co-founder Sanjeev Bikhchandani acknowledged that investing in the startup was a mistake.Founded in November 2020, 4B Networks facilitated communication and business transactions between real estate developers and brokers through its Broker Network Platform. The platform also helped brokers conduct site visits and offer home-loan-related services to clients. Info Edge’s subsidiary, Allcheckdeals India Pvt Ltd (AIPL), had invested Rs 288 crore, including Rs 12 crore as debt financing, in 4B Networks.
Article Summary: Info Edge has filed a first information report (FIR) against Rahul Yadav, the founder of its portfolio company 4B Networks. Info Edge’s subsidiary, Allcheckdeals India Pvt Ltd (AIPL), had invested Rs 288 crore, including Rs 12 crore as debt financing, in 4B networks.

A Virginia man, Naresh Bhatt , has been charged with the murder of his wife, Mamta Bhatt , four months after her disappearance. Article Title: Bengaluru woman outsmarts cabbie’s fake tech glitch scam; know how
Article Text:

The driver’s attempt to mislead

In an age where technology facilitates convenience, instances of scams in ride-hailing services have emerged as a concern for commuters. A Bengaluru resident recently faced such a situation but demonstrated exceptional composure and quick thinking to outwit a potential scam. Sharing her story on Reddit, she recounted her encounter with a low-rated ride-hailing driver. Despite being in a tense situation, her ability to stay calm and strategise helped her resolve the matter without escalating it. The story not only highlights the risks associated with ride-hailing services but also offers a lesson in handling such scenarios effectively.The incident occurred when the Bengaluru resident booked a Rapido cab from Central College to Hoodi, with the app quoting a fare of Rs 385. She noticed the driver had a low rating of 2.6, which raised initial concerns. However, due to heavy rain and the cab’s proximity, she decided to proceed with the booking.The journey was uneventful until the drop-off point when the driver demanded Rs 600, showing a screenshot as proof. The commuter immediately identified the screenshot as being from a previous ride and checked her app, which still showed the trip ongoing with no deviations.The situation took a turn when the driver logged out of his account and logged into another, presenting an empty ride history as evidence. He continued to insist on the inflated fare, citing server issues. Recognizing the scam, the commuter decided against direct confrontation. Instead, she pretended to sympathize with the driver’s explanation to de-escalate the situation.“I played along, telling him I’d pay whatever fare my app eventually displayed, even if it was Rs 1,000,” she wrote in her Reddit post. She logged in and out of the app, connected to her home WiFi, and pretended to call Rapido’s SOS service.After a 20-minute standoff, she suggested paying Rs 385 upfront and sending the remaining amount via Google Pay once her app updated. This strategic approach, which she referred to as a “reverse-UNO of sympathy,” worked. The driver reluctantly accepted the original fare and left. Shortly after, the app confirmed the accurate fare of Rs 385.The commuter’s story garnered widespread attention on Reddit, with users commending her calm demeanor and resourcefulness.One user remarked, “It’s unfortunate that scams like this happen, but you did a smart job staying calm and not allowing the driver to pressure you into paying more.”Another added, “Your approach of de-escalating the situation was admirable. Filing a complaint against the driver could help others avoid similar incidents.”Others highlighted the risks associated with low-rated drivers, emphasizing the importance of staying vigilant during such rides.
Article Summary: A commuter in Bengaluru faced a scam from a low-rated ride-hailing driver. Despite being in a tense situation, her ability to stay calm and strategise helped her resolve the matter without escalating it. Her story garnered widespread attention on Reddit, with users commending her calm demeanor and resourcefulness.

Article Title: Scientists use forensic technology to reveal ‘real face’ of 1700 years old Santa Claus
Article Text:
Image credit: Instagram

Take a look at the post here



Who was Saint Nicholas of Myra

What the scientist said about the real face of Santa Claus



“The skull has a very robust appearance, generating a strong face, as its dimensions on the horizontal axis are larger than average. This characteristic, combined with a thick beard, is very reminiscent of the figure we have in mind when we think of Santa Claus,”

“We initially reconstructed the skull in 3D using this data. We supplemented this with the anatomical deformation technique, in which the tomography of a living person’s head is adjusted so that the virtual donor’s skull matches that of the saint. The final face is an interpolation of all this information, seeking anatomical and statistical coherence,”

Scientists have used facial reconstruction technology to reveal the likely face of Saint Nicholas, the 4th-century bishop who inspired the Santa Claus legend. By analysing data from Saint Nicholas 's skull, researchers created a detailed image showing a white-bearded man with a broad forehead, thin lips, and a round nose. According to lead researcher Cicero Moraes , the reconstruction combines "statistical projections" and "artistic" interpretation. Moraes also shared the “real face” of Santa Claus in an Instagram post.Saint Nicholas of Myra, renowned for gifting only well-behaved children, originally inspired the Dutch figure Sinterklaas , who eventually evolved into the jolly, sleigh-riding figure known in the US for bringing toys to children.In an interview with Pen News (seen by The New York Post), Moraes noted that although the bishop passed away in 343 AD, long before photography existed, the 3D images depict his face as both "strong" and "gentle."he said.Moraes also highlighted that he was surprised to discover how the scientifically reconstructed images closely aligned with early literary descriptions of Santa Claus, such as the 1823 poem *“Twas The Night Before Christmas,”* which highlights his “rosy cheeks,” “broad face,” and a “nose like a cherry.”Examination of the saint’s remains even revealed signs of chronic arthritis in his spine and pelvis, as well as a thick skull that likely caused frequent headaches, Moraes added.The scientists also suggested that Saint Nicholas likely followed a mostly plant-based diet. Originally buried in Myra (modern-day Turkey), his bones were later transferred to Bari, Italy, where they remain today.Moraes explained.
Article Summary: Scientists have used facial reconstruction technology to reveal the likely face of Saint Nicholas, the 4th-century bishop who inspired the Santa Claus legend. By analysing data from Saint Nicholas's skull, researchers created a detailed image showing a white-bearded man with a broad forehead, thin lips, and a round nose. The reconstruction combines "statistical projections" and "artistic" interpretation.

Article Title: 369 million malware threats and counting: Report reveals ‘dangerous’ scale of hacking in India
Article Text:
Key highlights of India Cyber Threat Report 2025

Seqrite launches solutions to mitigate cyber attacks

A new report has painted a concerning picture of India’s cybersecurity landscape. Seqrite , in collaboration with the Data Security Council of India (DSCI), has released the “India Cyber Threat Report 2025,” which highlights a staggering 369 million malware detections across the country.The report notes the increasing sophistication and volume of cyber threats targeting Indian individuals and organisations. It also highlights the most prevalent malware types, the most affected regions in the country as well as the top sectors that are particularly vulnerable to these attacks.As per the India Cyber Threat Report 2025 , there have been 369.01 million malware detections across an 8.44 million-strong installation base in India. Out of all detection, signature-based detection methods dominate at 85.44%, while behavior-based detection accounts for 14.56%.The report also provided a breakdown of malware subcategories – meaning the type of malware used in attacking individuals and organisations. As per the report, Trojans have been used 43.38% of total detections, followed by Infectors (34.23%), Worms (8.43%), and others.“The Android-based security detections reveal a concerning distribution of threats, wherein malware accounted for 42% of all detections, followed by Potentially Unwanted Programs (PUPs) as the second most common threat at 32%. Adware comprised 26% of detections in Android devices,” the report added.Coming to most affected regions, the report notes that Telangana, Tamil Nadu, and Delhi are the top three regions affected by malware attacks with healthcare, Hospitality, and BFSI being the most targeted sectors.Alongside the report, the company introduced Seqrite Malware Analysis Platform (SMAP) designed to empower security professionals with deep insights into suspicious files and URLs that may evade traditional detection methods.In addition to this, the company also launched Seqrite Threat Intel, a real-time Cyber Defense Hub powered by Seqrite Labs. This platform is set to offer comprehensive threat intelligence from diverse sources, including open-source intelligence (OSINT) and Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERTs).
Article Summary: Seqrite has released the ‘India Cyber Threat Report 2025,’ which highlights a staggering 369 million malware detections across the country. Article Title: Intel’s interim co-CEO ‘wants’ these qualities in the next company chief executive

Intel 's interim co-CEO David Zinsner has revealed the qualities that the company is looking for in its next chief executive. Chandrasekaran stated that the development of the 18A node is progressing as expected.“There's nothing fundamentally challenging on this node now. It is about going through the remaining yield challenges, defect density challenges,” he said.Intel plans to provide samples of chips made with the 18A node to customers in the first half of next year and begin mass production at its Oregon plant in the second half.Zinsner also expects the foundry business to achieve better margins next year, driven by the production of Lunar Lake processors and cost reductions.

Google DeepMind has introduced Genie 2 , an AI model capable of generating diverse and interactive 3D environments from a single image prompt. These environments can be used in games, animated movies and training embodied AI agents.Genie 2 builds upon its predecessor, Genie 1, which focused on 2D world generation. This new iteration expands into the realm of 3D, creating rich and dynamic virtual worlds that can be explored and interacted with.“Genie 2 could enable future agents to be trained and evaluated in a limitless curriculum of novel worlds. Our research also paves the way for new, creative workflows for prototyping interactive experiences,” Google DeepMind said.Google DeepMind has shared a bunch of use cases of this AI model, including:From a single image, Genie 2 can generate a wide variety of 3D environments, complete with objects, characters, and interactive elements.Users can interact with these worlds using keyboard and mouse inputs, allowing for human or AI agents to navigate and manipulate the environment.Genie 2 exhibits emergent capabilities, including object interactions, character animation, physics simulation, and the ability to predict the behavior of other agents within the environment.The model can maintain consistent world states for up to a minute, generating new and plausible content on the fly. Genie 2 can also generate environments from various perspectives, including first-person, isometric, and third-person views.Google DeepMind says Genie 2 is an autoregressive latent diffusion model, which has been “trained on a large video dataset. After passing through an autoencoder, latent frames from the video are passed to a large transformer dynamics model, trained with a causal mask similar to that used by large language models.”

Article Title: US senators call US immigration system broken, proposes new cap and these big changes
Article Text:
Also read:

US Immigration reforms that the bill seeks

Two Democratic Senators have introduced a new bill aimed at reuniting immigrant families and increasing the per-country caps for family-based immigration. Senators Mazie K. Hirono , a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Tammy Duckworth introduced the Reuniting Families Act , designed to reduce family-based immigration backlogs, and modernize immigration laws to align with current migration patterns.Mazie K. Hirono said “As the only immigrant currently serving in the US Senate, I am proud to introduce the Reuniting Families Act to update our country's family immigration system and promote family unity”.Explaining further, she said “By implementing changes to reduce the backlog of family-based immigration visas, exempting close relatives from visa caps, and preventing the separation of LGBTQ+ families, this bill will better prioritize family unity in our immigration system”.The proposed legislation aims to “recapture” unused visas from previous years, adding them to the pool available for distribution by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS). The bill also seeks to exempt close relatives, including spouses, unmarried children under 21, and certain parents of legal permanent residents, from visa caps. The cap refers to the limit of H-1B visas allowed per federal fiscal year (FY).Additionally, it aims to raise per-country limits on family-based immigration, allowing countries like India, China, Mexico, and the Philippines to access more visas. It grants the government discretion in applying certain “bars” on individuals, removing unfair requirements that force individuals who entered the U.S. unlawfully to return to their home countries to seek legal status.The legislation includes measures to protect children from "aging out" when they turn 21, extending protections to stepchildren and children of visa holders. It also expands the criteria for canceling deportation orders, making it easier for noncitizens to stay in the US if deportation would cause extreme hardship to a US citizen or legal permanent resident family member.Furthermore, the bill addresses discrimination against LGBTQ+ families by ensuring equal treatment for those in same-sex relationships. It allows refugee spouses and partners to be resettled together and enables spouses of individuals granted asylum to join them in the US.
Article Summary: US Senators Mazie K. Hirono and Tammy Duckworth introduced the Reuniting Families Act. The bill aims to reduce family-based immigration backlogs, and modernize immigration laws. It also seeks to exempt close relatives, including spouses, unmarried children under 21, and certain parents of legal permanent residents, from visa caps.
